Bottle share for phillybeerscene. Aroma is nice and sweet with tobacco, figs, raisins and brown sugar. Pours brown with very little lacing and no carbonation. Taste is very yummy. Dates, raisin, figs and brown sugar. Much sweeter than altbiers that I am used to.

Bottle.
Pours clear red chestnut with a small, creamy, beige film head. Aroma has toasted caramel, chocolate, plenty of plums and raisins and is light vinious. Medium carbonation, dry and creamy mouthfeel. Flavour is dry, lots of dark chocolate, hazel, dryness, light coffee, figs and biscuits. Light warming finish.

A - Dark brown with a finger of frothy khaki-tan head. Fades fairly quickly.

S - Sweet caramel malts, brown sugar, caramelized malts, some dark fruit, dark caramel malts, toffee, English yeast, nuttiness, vanilla, and some booze.

T - Sweet caramel malts, brown sugar, caramelized sugars, raisins and other dark fruits, darker caramel malts, nuttiness, vanilla, English yeast, and some booze.

M - Medium-full bodied with moderate carbonation. Smooth with a sweet and warming finish.

D - Nice balanced old ale. A touch on the thin side.
Bottle. Pours clear brown colored with a nice off white head. Aromas of toffee, biscuit, molasses, dried fruits and cherries. Sweet and boozy flavor. Great.
Pours translucent hazelnut. Aroma bursting with ripe plum and apricot. Beautiful well balanced molasses and caramel up front that has a well balanced long finish.

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2013 27th March 2011Cloudy dark brown beer, residual pale tan head. Smooth palate, dry. Fresh malt, a little creamy. Trace amount of chocolate. A little dry wood. Whisper of hop before a dry finish. All right. 15th August 2013GBBF Day 3. On sale as Alesmith Old Ale. Clear deep red - brown beer. Residual pale tan head. Smooth and semi dry palate. Rich toffee and dried fruits. Slightly bitter and a little woody. Sherry notes. Light dry finish. Mature and tasty!
Sampled in the bomber. Aged two years. A really finely malted brew that is bubbly but so smooth. A really fine palate.
Bottle from Pikkulintu, Helsinki. Colour is brown with small white head. Aroma and flavoirs are raisins, toffee and malta.

2005 vintage, 750ml bottle pours a translucent, copper amber with one clump of white head.  Nice nose, oxidized, light leather, orange, mint, brown sugar.  Flavor is minty, brown sugar, orange, toffee.  Medium bodied, lightly sweet finish.

UPDATED: DEC 17, 2016 75 cl bottle as Alesmith Decadence 2010 @ Olutravintola Pikkulintu. Rated on 4.12.2010
Aroma is rather sweet with lots of malt, some ripe fruits, caramel and toffee. Flavour is sweet with way too much grainy malt, caramel, ripe fruits and hints of biscuits. Very smooth and nice palate. Too sweet for me.

7-4-7-5-15=3.8

75 cl bottle @ olio
As Alesmith Olde Ale MMXV
Aroma has oaky tones, calvados, apples? Also sweet malt and caramel. Flavour has sweet malty tones, alcohol (non-disturbing), sweet liquor, calvados and woody tones. Finishes with minerals and woody tones. Good still.

7-4-8-4-15=3.8

Bottle with friends. Poured a murky brown red color. Aromas of cherry, cocoa, sugars, creamy malts, nice hop bite at the end. Other tasting notes of plum, spicy yeasts, roasted malt, and candy sugar. Excellent.

A knock-you-on-the-rear big beer.  Big mouth feel,great fruitiness, surprisingly hoppy.A real American take on this style.  I would like to drink more as so tasty but booze bill took its toll on us. Share with friends!
Gotten in trade.

75cl bottle at Håndverkerstuene. Brown colour with hints of a red hue and no head. Aroma is fruity, lots of dried fruits actually and malts. Notes of toffee and sweet caramel. Flavour is bitter the first second, but then the sweet and fruity notes take complete control. Hops are present as well. Alcohol and malts are also present. All in all its just to sweet.

2010 bottle. Again, not sure who I got this from but am grateful for the tasty AleSmith. Pours a cloudy amber with ruby highlights and a small, lasting off-white head. Aroma of caramel malts, dark fruits (figs, dates, raisins), brown sugar, spices, and something that hints at wood. Flavor of caramel malts, brown sugar, root beer, and woody booze. Medium-bodied, with moderate carbonation and a rich, warm mouthfeel. Very good.

2011 bottle from bofnjackson...thanks Matthew! - Pours murky mahogany with a bubbly light tan head. Herbal hops on the nose, with caramel, dark bread roast, chocolate, and a light boozy warmth. Tastes caramelly, with milk chocolate, light herbal hops, and a bit of milkiness. Bitter roast on the finish, with a touch of nuttiness. Very nice and smooth--a sipper, though less hot than what I would have thought.

750 ml bottle (2005 consumed in 2011) shared by shigadeyo.  Pours a clear deep copper color with a small off white film.  The aroma is big, sweet caramel and toffee, ripe fruits, tobacco and a hint of chocolate.  The flavors are much of the same with big caramel/toffee character, dark ripe fruits, tobacco, hints of chocolate and a splash of vanilla.  This was a treat to be able to try.  Tasted alongside the 2010 bottle this was the clear winner.  4.1.

The 2010 version had more alcohol showing and a bigger herbal component.  I think this will improve with more time. 3.8.

Pours dark brown with a big tan head.  Nose is caramel and ripe prunes and plums, very strong nose.  Flavor is fairly well balanced but hangs out on the side of sweet more than anything.  Mouthfeel is silky smoove and creamy.  Aftertaste is very long.  This is one in a line of amazing anniversary beers.

Dark amber/brown color; Medium creamy body; Aroma of toasted malt, caramel/toffee, dark fruit, & some alcohol; Flavor of roasted malt, caramel, molasses, chocolate, ripe dark fruit (notably figs & dates), some hops, and spice; Finish is slightly bitter; Very nicely balanced; Overall, ridiculously smooth - delicious brew.

Dark brown pour with a frothy beige head.  Aroma was big time sweet malt and dark fruit.  Almost like rum soaked raisins.  Flavors were big, sweet and malty.  Lots of fruit and booze.  Given the hugeness that was this beer it remained somewhat drinkable and nice.  Alesmith just doesnt miss, everything they do is straight to the point, always to style and top notch quality.  Thanks Santa for the bottle.

Dunkelmalzig-röstiger Geruch mit süßlichen Schwarzbrotnoten,  likörartig. Startet malzig-süß. Mitte hebt stark an malzsüß, ölig und röstig, Schokolade, Feigen. Abgang likörartig und wärmend mit süffigem Charakter.
Grandioses rundes Bier von enormer Fülle.
Bottle from Wallys in LA purchased in 10/10, drank in 8/11. Murky brown, red. A bit soapy. Tastes like a big old imperial red. The oxidation is fine, but doesnt work all that well.

Sample @ Stockholm Beer & Whiskey Festival
Figs, knäck, notes of cherries, raisins, dried apricot and very complex. Great  beer and great balance. Being as strong as it is, its easy to drink it.
Bottle shared at home in Skövde. Dark amber, hazy with a beige head. Dried fruits, raisins and some hoppy aroma. Malty, hoppy bitter flavor with herbs. To bitter for me.

750ml purchased at Whole Foods, Santa Barbara, CA back in July.  deep amber / ruby / brown pour with a small off white head.  sweet fruit nose with layers of grapes, prunes, figs, dates, raisins and sweet caramel malts.  medium to full body with a big sweetness throughout.  more dark fruits.  some residual sweetness.  a touch of smoke and light wood flavors.  sweet finish with a touch of alcohol, lots of dark fruits and cinnamon.  nice beer.
4/5 in darkness. Smells caramell malty. Sweet caramell malty taste with a similar finish.

75 cl bottle, thanks to tkrjukoff. Amber beer, nice creamy beige head. Malty nutty aroma, hazelnuts, earthy and a bit sweetish. Malty nutty fruity flavor, figs and raisins notes, some hops, some grass. Very nice balance, and so drinkable.

Bottle (75 cl), courtesy of tkrjukoff. Clear deep chestnut with medium beige head. Deep fudgy, caramelly malt aroma, with notes of dried fruits, and piney, perfumy hops. Medum bodied with soft carbonation. Semi dry with medium bitterness.

Bottle Ølbutikken, Copenhagen. Pours clear ruby mahogany  with a nice creamy head leaving lace. Aroma is fruity, sweet, raisins, madeira and malty. Very nice. Flavor is sweet, raisins, dark fruits, alcohol, malty and bitter tart. Great. Finishes dry tart bitter.

Thanks to absolutesites, I had an opportunity to try this at the 2nd Pgh Tasting on the 2nd. First off let me say that my palte is so immature that I should not be allowed to rate such refined beers, this is way outtah my league. From a big bottle as pictured. Yes, smell is ceratinly leathery and old. Looks somewhat like cream soda without a head.  Big giant taste bud impressions leave me recovering in the back of my mind.  Bitter, strong and alky. Does taste old fer sure. Way too much for my crying out loud girlie taste buds. I would think this is the anti-civilized of civilized. Over the top and quite impressive to say the least. Dont know what others see in this and after 5 yeasr I guess my palate will never mature. Barely any co2 in this beer. Oily and mouth coating finish, almost cloying at times. Although I am not qualitifed to rate such a beer, I want to thank James for his kindness in letting me do so. At first he wasnt going to, he had me in a head lock for a while but then he relented!
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Brown-red, beige cover.  Aroma is bready, caramel, candy.  Taste is sweet, more bready, caramel.  Kinda ok.

750ml bottle in a snifter.  Pours ruby/brown with a lacy, beige head.  Aroma of cereal, slightly roasted and chocolatey, and caramel malts, strong floral and almost citrusy hops, and some alcohol.  Flavor a really nice blend with the alcohol being hidden well.  Thick texture.  A really good beer.

750 ml bottle purchased at the brewery 13 months ago ($11.99).  Pours a nice reddish-brown hue with one finger of tan head.  Aroma of sticky overripe dark fruit, caramel, brown sugar, molasses, and some booze at the end.  Flavor of rich toffee, port wine, smooth creamy chocolate, dark fruit, and a hint of cherry.  Sweet, but not to the point of being cloying.  Remarkably smooth for an 11 percenter.  Glad I aged this for over a year, but I think it could benefit from even more cellar time.  (428, 595)

Big bottle kindly shared by gunnar. Hazy mahogany with a beige, creamy film. Malty and roasted aroma. Sweet and alcoholic flavors with chocolate and toasted notes. Smooth, fullbodied drink with a nice alco warmth.

Bottle (from the november 2005 RB-tasting at Dixens place - notes have been damaged by flooding of my basement, but this was such an insane tasting for me as I was new to such massive tastings, so I gave up on the detailed notes quite early). Hazy red/brown. Alcohol, prunes and plums. Velvet in the throat. All that was readable from the notes...

Bottle courtesy of ketchepillar. Pours a deep rd with a small well retained head and great lace. The aroma is orange rind and mild caramel with some cherry. The flavor is fairly hoppy even though its over a year old. There is plenty of caramel with some fairly spicy notes and a bit of dark fruit. The palate is full and the carbonation is nice. Pretty tasty beer.

Macerated pit fruits, big raw sweet grains, and yeast with everclear moonshine type finish.  Loose and light mouthfeel that pushes and alcohol wisp up the nose.  Flavor is of Tomasellos Almondique liquor with sharper alcohol and less refinement.

Bottle at local tasting. Pours mahogany with a big creamy light tanned head. Aroma of toffee and chocolate, liquorice and alcohol. Taste is smooth malty, oily mouthfeel, chocolate, lingering sweet aftertaste.

Shared bottle at local tasting, as AleSmith Decadence Anniversary Ale, English Style Old Ale (2010), thanks to gunnar. Dark brown colour, low beige head. Intense malty aroma, notes of molasses, hints of oak and dark dried fruits. Rich and warming mouthfeel. Rich and intense malty flavour, notes of molasses and dark dried fruits. Decent hops in the finish.

Bottle shared by the Bastardos at Muckfest II on 6/25/11. Clearish copper pour with a thin off-white head. Malty and grainy nose with a bit of fruit and earthy hops. Caramel and grainy malt flavor with a bit of fruit before a bready finish.

Bottle. Plenty of caramel malts. Thin head strong body of pronounced sweetness. Flat carbonation. Taste like it has been casked in oak for some time.  A brew to be enjoyed after dinner eventually with cheese.

From a Friday night mini-tasting at Proof.  Sorry, dont remember who brought it in.  Butterscotch aroma - caramel sweet malt - banana bread - tacky bitter finish - hides alcohol well - just a little warmth - 7.4

(Bottle) Pours deep mahogany brown with deep red highlight. Off-white head. The aroma is fat malty with tones of dark juicy bread, caramel and light burned cookies as the most notable. A touch of dark cherries (oxidation) in the background. Earthy, spicy and light wooden hops. Touch of doughy yeast, dried fruits, bitter, nutshell and milk. Whisper of alcohol. The bready, dark grainy malt bill gives a real, almost German felling to the nose. The flavor is medium sweet, light to medium bitter and light acidic. Tones of earth, spices, light citric, dark bread, caramel, burned toffee and dough alongside a light milk touch. The malt profile is fat, almost buttery. The mouthfeel is round, fat and soft with light to medium carbonation. Caramelly and bit too yeasty alongside a touch of liquorice root on the finish.  Near full bodied. Super yummy, just some minor flaws.

Dark brown pour with reddish tints. Aroma and flavor are both marked with monstrous dark fruit, notably plum, fig, raisin, and some sweet molasses. Palate was rich, but still struck me as a tad thin. Good, but with a bit of age I think this would be much better with some extra nuances that arent here when its this young.
Super dark pour with a lively white head. Lots of dark fruit incarnations- plum, fig date, and prune with burnt caramel, toffee, and molasses. Super thick mouthfeel with a sugary sweet finish.

Deep Brown Pour, 
Aroma is sweet raisin, plum, brown sugar, caramel malt.  Flavor is rich, decadent and sweet with candied dates, spice, rich caramel/toffee maltiness.  Big malty beer, nice and deliciously to style.

Great beer. It doesnt mesh well with my palate, but i can appreciate the work put into this beer.  The aroma is of an english style ale with a taste that has a very cherry  like middle. It has a sweet malt flavor with some light hop notes that help to balance it. Although the taste is overwhelmingly alcohol and sweet malts. Good beer, just not my style. I should have put some more age on this to be honest.

Pours a deep brownish black with thin cover of tan head. Aroma pungent and layered; raisin, plum muted caramel sweetness, licorice. Viscous mouthfeel. Big malty bite with a strong support of floral hops. Finish is long and lingering, alcohol warming but not too hot. Exquisite.

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2013 750mL bottle, split with manuchampions, pours murky dark reddish brown with a beige head. Nose is full of plum, raisins, figs, dates (dark dried fruit galore), caramel, slight licorice and a decent amount of sweetness. Flavour suggests a barley wine, with heaps of caramel, dark dried fruits, just the right amount of English hops, and some candied sugar. Excellent stuff.

Thanks to overlord for the bottle. Served in a snifter.

Pours a very dark brown color with a fairly large head for the style. Bubbly tan head with a good cap and collar throughout. The nose has a subtle sweetness with a bit of fruit and some caramel plus brown sugar. Slight amount of booze there as well. The taste is a bit more plain and quite mellow. Booze comes back again. There is a slight brown-sugar sweetness there and mild fruits throughout. This is good, but not the caliber I expect from AleSmith. The feel consists of a medium body with light carbonation. This is pretty drinkable for now, but it seems like it needs more time to mellow out a bit.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-29-2010

Thank you Josh for opening this 6 year old bottle to celebrate the birth of your second baby. It pours dark amber in color with a little white head. There is some sweetness and definitely syrup notes in the aroma. For the age, there is some major potency going on here, tastes of massive brandy flavors with some light pleasant caramel notes. The body is pretty thick, but smooth for an old ale on my palate.

Opened slightly chilled.  Pours a deep reddish-brown color with a thin frothy head on top that mostly gets pushed off to the sides.  The aroma is of fruit cake, plums, raisins, brown sugar, a bit of tobacco, and caramel.  This drinks very smooth with a soothing brandy flavor, some bready notes thats probably the fruit cake noted in the aroma, sweet tobacco, red plums, raisins, and toffee.  Warming going down but not hot.  Its a bit sweet and candy-like but smooth boozy notes and light hops round it out nicely.  Well done.  I cant say that Im surprised.

Bottle @ Brewdog Edinburgh. Brownish-purple colour, off-white head. Aroma is malty, raisins, plums, red fruits. Flavour is malty, raisins, fruity, with a little hop kick, some breadiness. Sweet and dry finish. Very enjoyable.
UPDATED: APR 3, 2011 Bottle @ BrewDog Bar, Edinburgh. Strong sweet malty aroma & flavour. Dark brown colour with good head. Sweet aftertaste. Not really to my taste.

from erzbierschof.ch - cloudy ruby-brown in colour and with a chaotic beige foam left; slightly toasted malty aroma with notes of marzipan, chestnuts and berries; light woody tones; full-bodied and with a fair sweetness, solid bitterness and a long flowery malty and nutty finish; some notes of warming alcohol

Bottle from a trade with cbkschbert. Pours dark brown with tan head. Aromas of dark fruits, toasted malts and molasses. Sweet molasses flavor with some caramel and figs. Medium body with moderate carbonation. Another excellent Alesmith brew. Thanks Craig.

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2014 Bottle; Yeah. Pour is dark brown/black , with amber highlights as well. Off white head - retention is on the modest side, and lacing is quite modest.  Brandy, Dark fruits, and a heavy malt profile dominate the nose, honestly. Slightly hot and boozy, but fairly epic, really. Tobacco, Brown sugars, dark fruits, and brandy tops off the flavor profile. But lest we forget the bit of peat present as well. This brew is one of those wow brews , really. 

Well. At least it was - but the palate has become a bit refined - I cracked open a modern old ale branded bottle yesterday and I guess it really has been 3 years. Oh well, I guess I was more dramatic in the early days

25.4 oz bottle, 2010.  Purple brown with lacy froth.  Nose is grapes, hay, toffee and raisin.  Mouthfeel is full, lush and saturated leaning toward syrupy.  Buzzy then hot.  Taste is raisin, dates and brandy.  Finishes with honey and burnt sugar.  Yum.
Bottle thanks to DaSilky. Pours clear reddish brown. Nose and taste of caramel, toffee, brown sugar and light peat. Clean.

Massive, frothy tan head that leaves sticky lacing down the side of the glass.  Ruby brown beer that is somewhat transparent.  Aroma is dry peat, caramel, toffee, and soft, light roasted malt and sweet malt.  Taste is slight bitter hops, peat, caramel/toffee, and noticeable barley wine raisin with a fairly clean and dry finish.  Subtle, complex, and extremely drinkable.
Wow, what a good old ale, best Ive ever had. Very rich compex perfectly balanced malt and hop profile, highly recommended

Bottle, has been in the cellar for about 7-8 months. Pours a dark reddish brown with head that faded quick but lingered around the edge. The aroma is that of sweet malts, dark fruit, and caramel. Flavor is much of the same only slightly sweeter and with a bit of booze. The mouthfeel is silky smooth. I really wish I had a few more bottles of this to age because I bet it only gets better.

Bottle at Brewdog bar, Aberdeen. Pours amber with a ruby highlights and rapidly dissipating beige head. The nose is redcurrants, orange peel, honey, bread, caramel, brown sugar and English hops. The taste is caramel, obvious orange, plenty of dark fruits (raisin, plum, cherry), varnish, cinnamon, clove, wood and vanilla. Its an interesting beer to share with friends during the colder months of the year.

Thanks to Thomas for bringing this along to the Merton Beer Festival to share with us. It must have cost a packet!  Ruby black with a tan head and plenty of lacing. Flavoursome and balanced with rich plum pudding complexities, well masked alcohol, some wood and noticable fuggles/goldings hops. I would liked to have savoured this more on its own but was in the middle of hammering some far more sessionable beers at Fins fine festival. Once again, thanks for the generosity. I cant normally afford to experience beers like this.

750ml, gold foiled bottle from south bay. pours a beautiful, rich mohogany with a thick, creamy, light khaki head and sticky rings of lace. aroma is great with sweet candi sugar, pralines, and dried apricots with notes of orange liquour (definitely getting some Grand Marnier here), tangerine citrus, prunes, and wet grass with subtle notes of molasses, vanilla, and winter spices. flavor is wonderful as well with rich notes of molasses, toffee, and sweet, bready malts up front backed by sweet, dried fruit notes of cherry, fig, and orange, candied walnuts, and grassy hops with a crisp, spicy bite of booze on the finish. palate is full bodied with smooth carbonation and a rich, sweet, desert-like presence on the tongue. overall, another first class beer from alesmith.

Bottle kindly shared by Thomas at Merton Winter Beer Festival, thank you Thomas for your generosity 05.02.11  Pours a dark orangey brown I suppose there was some head but I never took any notice. I was convinced that this had some sort of barrel ageing, not that it was strong but there was whisky, wet wood and plenty of spirity vibes in here. Warmth from the alcohol, there is a lovely smooth malty and fruity depth here some vanilla and spice thrown in for good measure. Very nice and the sort of beer that is nice to share, I dont think I could have had a whole bottle to myself :-)  A7 A4 T8 P5 Ov15

Bottle; bought from Brewdog.com, shared with Bob, Fin, Glen, Loz, folk of Merton @ Merton Winter Beer Festival 2011. Bottle is a nice big bomber!

LOVE the artwork on the bottle and the general design concept. This is a stunning label and I must say hats off to Alesmith for producing wonderful hand-written notes on the bottle. Stunning to look at and an enjoyment tor read. More breweries can learn from this. 

Loads of old spices; raisins, hazlenut, lots of chocolate and hops on the nose. Taste is oak, Christmas pudding, slight tad of port, hazlenut, burnt raisins. chocolate, marzepan, some some candi-sugar, oak, maybe some barrel aging was done for this. 

Really enjoyed this us interpretation of English ale and the hops worked well but it was a tad too malty and very meaty in the mouth. Would LOVE to lay this down and see it develop. A great brew and an excellent beer to share and discuss. Perfect for a group discussion as it is so complex and big I can sniff and taste for hours whilst contemplating. Ideal brew for the fireside and winter nights. PERFECT for the winter.

Bottled, many thanks to tdtm82 (Thomas), also drunk with bobinlondon and Fin. Black with slight head. Port and whisky combination on the nose, plum pudding, then in drinking it there is a full on alcohol zap, with tar, bitumen and Whisky malt. There is a surprising bitterness for so high an ABV, finishes with prunes. Very complex and probably what made me fall asleep on the train back. Cheers boys.

True to its name, the Alesmith Decadence is a conversation between the Baroque and the Gothic. It transports one to a time in which Handel reigned supreme and Hildegaard of Bingen was not far behind. This is a prude beer as it gives no head, or not quite enough to get your engine a-running. That being said, this beer is quite promiscuous; youre just another notch on its proverbial belt. What it lacks in prudence it more than makes up for in acumen. The smell is of lavender, yellow roses, and charred Yugoslavian horned melon. One can see ones own past, present, and future upon gazing into her spiraling depths - an oracle, of sorts. It lavishes the tongue in a style reminiscent of the fresh milk of the renowned Northern Flemish steer. And the taste? Sublime: hints of blue grapes, smoked caramel, non-pareils, ecstasy, candied chestnuts, beer, and Latvian leeks. In a word: not bad. This beer is more fit to bathe in than to sup. Yet sup I will, I shall - nay, I must. And oh, how I shall sup!

05 and 10 next to each other. 05: chestnut brown, light red. thin wispy beige head. Candi Sugar, bubble gum, and toast. Flavor has moderate oxidation, light cardboard with chocolate, light malt up front, but burnt through finish. Bit sticky, full body, lingering Graham cracker flavor. Nice, not quite holding up but still very nice, heftier north coast x. 74741410: Decadence - way flatter, thinner than 05. Body is translucent nut brown, thin white ring for a head. Nose is light lactic, like BA Wee Heavy. Bit of vegetal bubble gum. 636312.

Pours a deep mahogany brown with a tanned head. The first thing that hit me is how smooth and mellow (in a good way) everything about this beer is. Dried fruits and caramel in abundance with a  bourbon vanilla sidekick. Liquid fruitcake kind of. A little sweet. Big body with a soft carbonation.
75cl, Vintage 2010, exclusive American brew, thx to Jeppe!, very complex brew, malty and fruity, not too heavy, very balanced, hazy, good head, top class!, yet expensive

750 mL bottle from South Bay Drugs.  Muddy brownish-orange pour with a creamy off-white head.  Aroma of tangerines, brown sugar, toffee, caramel, and whiskey.  The flavor is more subtle than the aroma with sweet caramel malts, light citrus, and brown sugar with hints of vanilla and oak that become more prominent as this warms.  Very excellent overall.
2005 vintage.  Pours a clear orange-brown with a tan head.  Malty aroma with bread and caramel.  Very smooth bready flavor.  Notes of molasses, bread, and caramel.  Very mellow.  Bitter finish.

Pours deep reddish brown, white head.  Aroma has notes of dark fruit, caramel, burnt toast, molasses, toffee, touch of booze, some vanilla.  Taste is a nice balanced brew, no sign of alcohol even warmed.  Notes include nice caramel, dark fruit, and toffee up front, leading into rich molasses and vanilla sweet middle, finishing a bit dry and sweet.  Excellent, complex brew.
Tons of gingerbread, ground coffee beans, cherries, toffee, cherries, moderately sweet, but just the right amount.  Cask at the linkery.  A touch of whisky in the finish.  Unbelievable.

Pours hazy reddish orange. Aroma is bold and fruity but you can smell the booze. Nice flavour very fruity. Very belgian. This is a very nice beer. Tastes like fruit cake. This is fantastic. Great beer!

Bottle, thanks to bman1113vr. Pours clear amber/tawny/brown, no head, no lacing. Carbonation is VERY soft! Nose is soft fruit, light nuts and vanilla, nice and soft and mildly sweet. Flavours run to the fruit and caramel.... Neither English nor Belgian in style... Something... Else.... Rather sticky mouthfeel owing to soft carbonation; flavours are toasty, mildly boozy, nice fruit and toast, butter, butterscotch, rum. Nice, not exceptional, but nice.

bottle poured a brown in color with a thin covering of tan head. aroma has malts, dark sugar, caramel, and smooth dark fruit. mouth feel coats well and the carbonation is real low. flavor is thick on the malt, fig, brown sugar, molasses, a bit of wood, and little alcohol considering the strength. definitely rich and a little woodsy with a bit of sweetness but the beer is solid and enjoyable.

Bottle from Ølbutikken, Copenhagen. Originally intended for New Years Eve 2010, but I decided after all to enjoy this in solemn indulgence instead of in a noisy, festive atmosphere. Will be my last rating for 2010, which has been a great year for me, beer-wise. And otherwise, for that matter. :-) Pours a deep mahogany-red body with a small, short-lived, off-white head. Nose is licorice, roasted malts, caramel, alcohol, wood and hints of honey, chocolate and molasses. Nice. Taste is burnt sugar, caramel, toast, wood, booze and molasses, with hints of licorice. Smooth palate. Solid stuff; very complex and a true winter warmer in these freezing Norwegian Christmas days. A strong contender from AleSmith, and I am looking forward to tasting more of their beers in 2011. A Happy New Year to all you wonderful beer geeks out there; see you in the next decade! :-D
Dark brown with with a thin fizzy tan head. Caramel toffee and cereal grain aroma and taste with a good molasses presence. Nice smooth creamy palate.

nice old ale reminescent of a wee heavy in its malty sweetness with enough hops to balance it out. color is absolutely perfect, nearly black but with flecks of brown when held into the light. decent tan head that doesnt disspate but leaves a nice lacing on the glass. ful mouthfeel and a lingering malt burn, and really the only criticism is that the malt aftertaste turns into a little bit of a cough medicine flavor. but it is a very good interpretation of the style, very enjoyable.
clear brown, smooth vanilla brown head.4 toasted bready caramelly aroma, 7 flavor is complex figs, dark caramel, malts, raisins, deep and complex flavor.  rich. Flavorfull.

Bottle shared at Pauls Thanksgiving tasting. The 05 vintage. Pours amber with a thin head. Dark malty aroma with some dark fruity sweetness. The flavor is sweet with some toasty malty notes, dark fruits and low bitterness. Solid, especially for its age.

Rusty, copper pour with a loose, frothy, off-white head.  The aroma is nutty with notes of cherry, molasses, some faint woodiness, caramel, vanilla, toffee, and some noble hops and alcohol.  The flavor is the same with a lingering, sweet brown sugar taste left on your lips.  Sticky, soft, medium body with moderate carbonation.

bottle thanks to stefanj.  poured deep amber/ruby with an off white head.  aroma was caramel, raisin, toffee, and chocolate.  flavor was caramel, toffee, raisin, and pine.  body was slicky and sticky with low carbonation.  a really great beer.

Bottle at home - shared with Mette. Clear dark red/brown - offwhite head. Red berries, nutty, fruity, licorice, nice but light hoppy, dried fruits, vineous, light chocolate, high malty, light citric notes. Nice.

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2011 Big sugary caramel nose, little floral on the back end.  Dark caramel in the glass, small white head.  Little hot, still young.  Sweet toffee up front, thins out fairly quickly, little rose petal in the finish, little metallic.  Saving another bottle.    05 bottle provided from suzygreenburg in september 2009 proved to be much better.  Old basement aroma, cranberry spice.  Hazy dark brown.  Some honeydew, lots of caramel, still heavy and strong after all these years.  Beautiful.

(Bottle, 0.75 l, at Pikkulintu) The beer poured dark brown and clear. Its head was medium sized and white. Aroma had malts, alcohol and fruit cake. Palate was full bodied and dry with medium carbonation. Flavours were malts, sweetness, alcohol, midly roastedness, molasses, hops and btterness. Aftertaste was sweet and bitter. An enjoyable brew in which alcohol was present too much giving the beer a harsh flavour. Ageing would quite like improve the beer.

Bottle: Poured a slightly cloudy amber color ale with a large frothy head with good retention and excellent lacing. Aroma of caramelized malt with residual sugar notes and lightly dry fruits notes. Taste is a great balanced mix between some dry fruits and caramel malt with light residual sugar. This one almost taste like an English barleywine and hops do not play a dominant roles. Body is about average with good carbonation and no apparent alcohol. Very well brewed and more balanced then most other beers form this brewer.

Deep caramel pour.  Little lacing. Toffee, mild hop nose. Sweet and malty with a really bitter finish. Very good, but doesnt quite cusp over into great.  I would definitely like to try this again though.


From sample pour at local December 2010 tasting.

Bottled 750ml @Pikkulintu
Dark red color, small steady beige head. Caramel, vanilla, liquer, banana (!) in the aroma. Full-bodied. Quite alcoholic. Roasted, ryeish maltyness, some chocolate, vanilla. Typical strong barley wine. Too rough, needs ageing.

(Bottled, 0.75l) Clear darkish red with a small head. Very strongly grainy-malty nose with sweetish dried fruit and anise spiciness. Flavor is dried-fruity, mildly spicy, sweetish, quite bitter with a dry finish. Quite full body with warming alcohol and low CO2. Good and balanced, but not exciting. 6738

750 ml bottle.  Pours a mostly clear deep reddish brown (more brown than red) with a moderate tan head that lasted through the first half of the glass and left a solid curtain of foam with each sip.  Very pleasant aroma of malt, caramel, raisins, prunes, and vanilla.  The flavor follows the aroma pretty closely with rich malt, caramel, raisins, prunes and vanilla.  Nice silky mouthfeel.  Only as the beer warms does the alcohol emerge towards the finish.  This beer drinks more like a quad than an old ale.  Excellent.
Bottle at ÖBWF 2010. It poured an almost clear mahogny liquid with a small beige head. Sweet flavour of sugar, caramel, malt, raisin and grapes. Very nice and malty with a complex flavour.

750 ml bottle. Mahogany brown with a small creamy head. Aroma of caramel, dried dark fruit, vanilla, toffee and oak. The flavor is malty but not overly sweet, same dessert like flavors from the aroma. There is some very mellow bitterness but only for balance. Full body with mild carbonation and a soft, smooth mouth feel. So good, dessert in a glass and very drinkable, thanks for this one GT.
Bottled 75cl. Ordered from www.bierkompass.de. Full bodied, sweet with not much bitterness. Boletus reminiscence throughout. The alcohol is very nicely hidden. A bit dissapointing.

Poured from a 750 ml bottle.  Pours dark brown with minimal head.  Smells of toffee and some dried fruits.  Very sweet.  Incredibly drinkable.  Loads of malty goodness.  I have stockpiled a few of these...I will be sad when they are gone.
Bottle.  Glad I got to try this Alesmith gem.  Big caramel malt, toffee, and vanilla flavors.
Tasted 2010-11-06. Part of an old ale tasting at Einar & Guddie. Pours amber. Strong, malty scent. Hops gives you pineapple. Very sweet, and very heavy, but surprisingly easy to drink.
Pours amber  Not much head. Very strong malt and yeast aromas, slightly sweet. Flavor is sweet, malty yeasty, alcohol. With a little age this thing will be %$^*

Bottle pours deep amber with a khaki head.  Aroma shows notes of caramel/toffee, vanilla, wood, dark fruit, and booze.  Flavor shows the same with a little roastiness popping out.  Overall body is moderate to full. Starts with malt sweetness and ends with dry oak, and warming alc.  Good stuff.
750 ml bottle.  Chestnut color, clear, no head.  Aroma of summer fruits.  Taste is similar, boozy.  Not bad.

Bottle from a recent trade. Aroma is a bit sweet and some bittersweet roasted malt. Flavor is incredibly complex yet hard to nail down considering each sip is a little different. At first I get a bit of a bittersweet roasted malt and it reminds me of a stout. Then I get a little more of the texture and it is a little more gritty and earthy. You can really eff this style up but once again Alesmith does it and it is pretty entertaining and tasty.

750ml bottle from somewhere in NY. Pours hazy amber with tan head. Aromas of caramel, toffee, sweet malts, and some dark fruits. Flavor of sweet caramel malts, toffee, dark fruits, and a bit of booze. Finishes sweet with silky mouthfeel. Really solid beer.
bottle at brewdog bar ... hazy red brown ... sweet vanilla bourbon nose ... sweet fruits ... lots of cherry ... toffee vanilla malts ... caramel...

Bottle.  Pours a clear ruby brown with a medium sized beige head.  Malt, a little roast, big caramel.  Loads of roast in the body, but its competing with boozy oxidized malt.  Long bitter roast malt and a good bit of oxidization on the finish.

Bottle: pours a dark brown with a thin tan head, aroma of chocolate, dark fruit, smells a little boozy as well, taste is sweet, malty, toffee maybe?, warming finish.  A nice old ale but I think the HOTD Adam is much better.

Pours dark mahogany into a snifter. Off-white head with medium retention recedes to hug rim. Toasted caramel and mild oak aromas.  Nutty french toast upfront turning slightly hot in the oaked resin finish.

Hazy mahogany with a medium beige head. Sweet flavour with roasted malt, caramel, toffee and overripe fruits. Sweet flavour with roasted malt, caramel, overripe dark fruits, hops and toffee notes. Finished sweet. Slightly oxydized but still quite nice.

Pours a dark amber with a thick tan head; sudsy and streaky. The nose isfloral and very bubbly, the smell of pine and toasted malt. The taste was sweet and malty, It has a slight vegtable and earthy note. It is very well carbonated and has good hop flavor.

Hazy brownish/garnet pour light tan head ... malty caramel aroma and a light hop .... taste of lots of caramel malts and sugar that hides any warming abv taste i anticipated in the finish ... very smooth and rich/sticky body and a light bitter hop in the finish .... dangerously smooth and drinkable

Pours a cloudy medium to medium dark orange. Aroma consist of caramel with hints of coffee toffee and booze.Palate is thicker than expected. Slight metallic flavor. Notes of Wood and vanilla with cream also present. slightly chalky.

Bottle, rate #700. Brilliantly clear ruddy brown to amber hue; thin layer of off-white head dissipates to a thin ring. Nose is dark fruits, alcohol warmth, molasses-brown sugar, bread/toast, caramel. Flavor is caramel and toffee sweet up front balanced by subtle english hops for bitterness, faint tones of lighter and darker fruits, figs, treacle, anise, hints of roast from the malts, finishes sweet and warming. Medium-full body, near flat carbonation, slick texture. A well-balanced old ale with plenty of English-type attributes, a bit less pronounced than its barleywine cousins, tastes a bit young, could definitely benefit from aging for a few years. I look forward to a re-taste down the road!

750ml bottle shared by no other than footbalm himself, thanks again 
Appearance: Poured hazy caramel color with a small beige head and some lacing 
Aroma: Caramel, toffee and malts, 
Taste: Toasted malts, caramel and figs 
Very nice.

This poured a nice mahogany color with a small beige head. Aroma was lots of caramel, dark fruit and toffee. Flavor was thick chewy caramel malt, some spicyness, notes of figs and light earthy hops. Alcohol is hidden ridiculously well in this one. Another world class beer from Alesmith.

West USA trip 2010. On tap @ Alesmith. The aroma has apples, sugar and caramel. Dark brown coloured beer with an off-white head. The taste is sweet, has raisin, grapes, caramel. Good balance and a full body. NIce Decadence.

750ml Bottle:  Complex aroma of dark ripe fruit, malt, raisins, figs, plums, light tobacco, toasted caramel, and slight wood.  Poured very deep amber/brown in color with a small, tan head that diminished but lasted throughout as a film on top of the beer, as well as around the edges.  Cloudy.  Lightly sparkling.  Full of tiny and small particles throughout.  Flavor is light to medium sweet and lightly bitter.  Tastes of malt, wood, caramel, prunes, dark ripe fruit, slight cocoa, slight honey, hint of vanilla, toffee, and slight yeast.  Medium body.  Average texture.  Average carbonation.  Toasted caramel, toffee, malt, dark ripe fruit, prune, slight cocoa, and hint of vanilla finish.  11%ABV is completely hidden throughout.

8/20/10.  750mL with big thanks to Tim!  Nice red pour.  Big sweet fruit aroma with molasses, brown sugar, and a hint of roast.  The flavor is big sweet up front, mostly brown sugar, then fades to charred figs and more.  Very nice.

bottle, muddy brown orange with thin off white foam with bubbles, aroma of fig newtons, orange marmalade, flavors of malty biscuits, figs, brown sugar, roasted meat, nice long finish albeit somewhat hot

750ml bottle.  Pours a hazy medium brown color with a well-formed light tan head.  The aroma has loads of toffee and dark fruit notes, with a little spice.  Definitely smells like an English-style beer.  The flavor is sweet, as it should be, with huge notes of toffee, caramel, and toast.  Sugar plums, raisins, and dates as well, with spices, especially nutmeg.  Fairly full-bodied and a little syrupy even, with soft carbonation.  Another well-done beer from AleSmith, who very rarely misses the mark.  Paired well with a cigar.

Bottle...  Poured dark, amber, with a dark tan head.  Aroma of toffee malts, little bit of booze.  Very English, lots of malt sweetness, bitter, fruit rind-like earthiness.  Lots of toasted, caramel sweetness.  Like a pastry dessert.  Molasses, slight spice, and whiskey alcohol heat.

Another winner by the most consistent brewery out there!!!  Ruby red/crimson pour produced a moderate eggshell head that left a spot or two of lacing.  Rich toffee, caramel, and brown sugar hit the nose as well as the palate.  Still a bit of noticeable alcohol but this babys young.  This will, without doubt, age beautifully.  Enough carbonation to ignite the palate but still on the low end.  This one isnt extremely complex but it might develop that with time.

Pours a reddish murky brown color with an off-white soapy head.  Has an aroma of toffee and caramel with hints of grapefruit and resin.  Dark fruit sweet start.  Then the bitter hit with the caramel malts.  Nice carbonation hit at the same time.  Velvety caramel finish.  Has a barley wine feel to it, but with a thicker mouthfeel.  Damn tasty.  Love the old ales.  May pick up another one to age.

bottle pours dark brown with a tall cream head.  Aroma is toffee and caramel all the way with touches of clove and nutmeg.  Flavor is rich caramel malt, sweet toffee, mild fig notes with a lightly boozy finish.  Top notch.

Taster on tap at AleSmith. Pours dark with little head. Smells of dark fruits, raisins, plums, and a little bit of roastiness. Moderate mouth feel with medium carbo. Taste is much like the aroma. Great beer

(750ml bottle).  Shared with Reg and Mike.  Pours a hazy caramely color.  Aroma is boozy.  Alcohol soaked raisins?  Taste is somewhat sweet with some light bitterness.  Medium bodied and creamy texture.  Very nice beer.  Another wonderful, complex beer from Alesmith.

(750ml bottle thanks to ericandersnavy) clear rich ruby-brown, long lasting creamy bubbles. Nose of sweet toasty caramel, cream, brown sugar, and bourbon (yes i know its not barrel aged). Taste of toasty sweet caramel, cream, vanilla bean, and oats. Very creamy body, toasty sweet linger. Delicious!
Floral smells and caramel. Tastes like caramel, barleywine, and bourbon. I want to pour this on Golden Grahams. Am I right?!

A: The pour is a dark chestnut color with a fingers worth of khaki colored head.

S: Sweet and toasty malts with a hint of roast and coffee. A bit of alcohol and dark fruit underneath the toffee, caramel, and maple notes.

T: Not nearly as sweet as I expect from most old ales. A slight bitterness to it, but not in the usual hop sense. Toasted and burnt malts/sugars to this one, with some toffee and molasses. A definite fruit character to it as well, mostly plums and cherries.

M: Medium to full bodied, smooth and subtly carbonated. Not exactly thick and syrupy, but not very light, either.

D: This alcohol makes its presence known here, and this one hits quite hard. The beer is good, but not great and I would be interested to see how this ages.

Dark, clear reddish brown, with thick lightish tan head.  Sweet malts, caramel, toffee, dark fruit bread, and hints of chocolate.  Very smooth and creamy, with warming alcohol coming through (but not spikey heat).  Very nice beer.

Bottle on 7/21/2010 poured into a tulip glass produced a dark reddish-brown body with tan head.  Aroma of chocolate and coffee.  A myriad of flavors tantilize your tongue with the dominant ones being caramel, dark chocolate, roasted coffee, brown sugar, and toffee.  There is a light hoppiness in the finish which balances the ale perfectly.
Very dark very chocolate tasting, coffee tasting.Very strong tasting. Not one of my favorite beers.
From  a 22oz bottle,Taste like dark fruit roll and brown sugar,Dark Red in color ,frothy Head very appearing .AleSmith for a Win.

75cl bottle.   Red brown color with good clarity before pouring in the yeast.   lasting light beige head.   Caramel and dried date, fig, and raisin aroma.   The flavor is sweet with a rich caramel touch and a round, fruity yeast profile.   Hops are very mild and just show a touch of bitterness.   Alcohol is pretty smooth already, and adds a touch of fruitiness.   This tastes like they already aged it significantly before release.   A bit of dry bread.   Full bodied and smooth.   Mixing in the yeast gives it a dusty, bitter bite in the finish.   Good stuff, but a bit plain at this point.   A year or two might give it some more interesting fruitiness from oxidation, but this is already pretty rounded and smooth.   Seems much more like an English barley wine, and lacks and darker malt or funky character that I would look for in an old ale.

750ml bottle from South Bay.  Pours a beautiful clear sparkling burgundy with ruby highlights and a large fluffy tan head that lingers.  Aroma is a nice blend of malty goodness, with caramel, toffee, a variety of ripe and candied dark fruits, brown sugar, and some molasses and hints of chocolate.  Flavor is more of the same, with a great blend of malty goodness.  As always, AleSmith delivers excellence.

pours a dark ruby red to caramel brown, 6mm head what fades fast but leaves some bubbles around the edges. aroma is faint and slightly funky, but very sweet. the taste is nice, lots of brown sugar, banana bread, cinnamon, clove, and plenty of heat. this is pretty good now, but this tastes like it will get noticably better over the next few years. good stuff.

750 ML bottle.  Big amber/brown pour.  Moderate to light carbonation.  Aroma was caramel, bread, fruity hops.  Flavor screams barley wine, with lots and lots of brown sugar and caramel.  Hops are present, but blend in well.   Moderate heat, but there is no doubt that this is a big beer.   This is a quality beer, which is what I would expect from Alesmith.  However, I will re-rate this in December, because this is NOT working for me in this 90+ degree house.

750ml bottle. Rating #322. Very dark and dense red color with a tan head. Toffee and a light dark fruitiness are pretty prevalent in the aroma. More toffee and sweet caramel with some hops upfront, very decadent indeed and quite tasty. (1300)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: 750 ml bottle from bev4less. Pours a hazy chestnut brown with a medium off-white head that slowly fades to a 1/4 inch and holds. The aroma is moderate in strength with raisins, figs, hazelnuts, sweet malts and molasses. The flavor is similar to the nose with figs, raisins, dates, and molasses, set in a nutty-malty base. A fair amount of hot alcohol is present but it works and compliments the flavors. The palate is smooth and full. The finish is long with lingering nuts and figs. Overall: A very tasty brew, this should age well, its a good one sock away. Also, it paired very well with cold leftover turkey sandwiches.

Bottle.  Pours a dark Burgundy with a lacing tan head.  Aroma is dark fruits, chocolate and caramel with some floral and spicy note and a bit of alcohol.  Flavor is lots roasty figs, raisins, etc.  Some toasty smoky notes and some chocolaty port wine.  Bitterness is smooth and moderate.  Warming finish.  Full bodied with moderate carbonation.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2011 Tap 2010 ed at AleSmith. Poured a murky deep brown with a thin yellow head. No lace. Nose of rum raisin, soy sauce. Taste is soy sauce, raisins, figs. Bought a few bottles of this to age. Hopefully it develops as well over a 5 year period as the AleSmith staff said the 2005 Decadence bottles are drinking exceptionally well right now. 7/9/2010 7/3/6/3/13=3.2750mL 2005 ed courtesy of ygtbsm94. The original Decadence pours a clear, deep amber with a small, yellow head. Aroma is big time mint. Taste is big toffee, peanut brittle, some herbal and spicy balance. Dates and raisins present. Its yummy but not something to freak out about. 1/11/2011 6/3/7/4/14=3.4 750mL 2010 ed courtesy of MrChopin. This vintage pours with a better head, but has an oxidized apple aroma. Body is full of spicy alcohol with maple and brown sugar. 1/11/2011 5/4/7/4/14=3.4

Served from a 750 mL bottle from OTM. Excited that AleSmith redid the 05 that I never had the pleasure of trying.  This is a bottle of the 2010 rated 7/4/2010. The appearance is a deep wooden brown with some amber edges. The head developed into a nice frothy just off white head. The nose is very sweet with malt, caramel, cinnamon, oak. The flavors continue to please with sweet malts, oak, muscat grape, sugar, light smoke, fruity esters, nice English hop bitterness, chocolate, caramel.The mouth is medium to full bodied, wonderfully easy drinking with a slightly drying finish. Wow a fantastic brew to say the least, highly recommend!

Pours a deep brownish black with a tan head. Aroma is esthers, yeasts, brown sugar, toasted nuts, caramel, chocolate, malts. Flavor is roast, nuts, malt, dark fruits, chocolate, a little hot booziness and vinous. Thick mouthfeel, and very balanced. This is an awesome beer.

Decadence 2010
Appearance: Pours a dark brown with a thick, frothy beige head.

Aroma: Chocolate, charms caramel apple lollipop, white grape and booze.

Taste: Burnt caramel, dark chocolate, bitter hops, wood and alcohol.

Mouthfeel: Medium and very fizzy. Warm.

Overall: Incredible. I would argue this beer is ready now, even with warm youth on its side.

What a great beer. Pours ruddy, caramel brown with red highlights. Thin offwhite head with some lace. Smells big and sweet, sugary malty with a hint of cardboard and some hop spice. Tastes sweet and sugary, with some nice fruity hops through the middle and spice and alcohol on the finish. Good good good. Full body, very nice carbonation.

Pour from a bottle revealed a dark brown color with a tan head. Nice smells of sweet plum , and sugar. Super smooth on your palate. Decadent for sure caramel fruit, toffee, and minimal hop flavors. Rich and yummy. Nice long tasty finish. What is not to like. Great beer.

UPDATED: SEP 27, 2011 750 ml bomber purchased at BevMo Long Beach.

Pours a dark reddish brown with a slightly lasting off white foam head. Aroma is caramel, slight raisin notes, toffee, and burnt sugar. Carbonation is perfect for the style, slight syrupy mouthfeel, but that is to be expected. Met with an onslaught of maltiness that is quickly checked with a nice hop balance.  Can most liken this to a barley wine incorporating more caramel and possibly chocolate malts. Amazing. I will definitely recommend this beer to friends and drink again. Curious to see how it ages.

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2013 750ml bottle.Pours a deep opaque auburn brown with thin, soda-like head. Aroma is pungent, a little meaty, a lot sweet, caramel-y, modest hop bitterness, a bit earthy. Flavor is juicy fruits, lots of sugar, earthy yeast, good leafy, tobacco-y hop bitterness that wasnt evident in the aroma, Finishes thick but a bit flat. Other than that its held up well over the last 5 years.

EDIT: I should note this was a 2005 bottle, consumed in 2010. I dont know how this got lumped into the 2010 ratings.

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2010 750 ml trade acquired in a trade a few years ago- thanks man! Ive had this for some time, and I finally broke it out. Luckily, it is now going to be made again, and well have plenty to compare with. Anyway, pours a dark opaque copper color with a medium off-white head. The aroma is rich dusty tomes, a monks cellars dust, old dried fruit. The flavor is great; nothing off here at all I think, dried fruit, smooth rich caramel and toasted malts, sweet and dry. A wonderful experience. Re-rate: the 2010 fresh was much different. Less dry and musty and sweeter with more assertive caramel. Very nice.

Amber colour, beige head. Aroma is caramel malts, some mild grassy and floral hoppy notes as well as toffee, alcohol and some mild notes of yeast. Flavour is alcohol, fruits, toffee, mild grassyness as well as mild yeasty and herbal notes.

Bottle 750ml. @ yesprs Pre tasting before the Copenhagen beerfestival. [ Blindtasting Bottle #11. ]Unclear medium amber color with a small average, frothy and open, good lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, oxidide malt, dried fruit, tobacco - wood, light to moderate hoppy. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft, finish feel is moderate alcoholic. [20100506]

75 cL bottle. Pours hazy dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma is dense malty, caramelish, sweet, breadish and light fruity. Sweet dark malty, toffee, roasted, breadish and nice subdued fruity flavoured. Lingering roasted and breadish toffee flavoured. Smooth malty and fruity with a mild bitterness into a medium dry finish.

This bottle was shared by Drewbeerme. Thanks! Cloudy brown w/ only a little head. Malty, oxidized sherry-like character w/ some raisin and brandy. Lightly boozy in general. Rather thick and heavy, sticky but it works. Sweety nutty malts and chocolate are the main character. Mildly carbonated. This has aged very well. Or, I assume it has, because it tastes good now. Never tried it young.

750 ml bottle shared by Drew. Pours a very dark caramel hue, hazed and murky, with a loose bubbled offwhite head that clings to the edges. Aromas are fairly sweet, caramel and toffee, sweet malts with vanilla, some faint hoppings on the nose, a touch of alcohol warmth. Initial is warm toffee, caramel, vanilla, a bit stale, warm and thinner bodied than expected. Warmer, toffee, with caramel, florals, a touch of chestnuts and and jam. A touch of oxidized cardboard. Sweet, sufficient bitterness on the palate. Interesting, tasty

750ml bottle.  Lusciously sweet, malty nose, darkly fruity, flowery, rich and very lightly oxidized, with suggestions of toffee, raisin, brown sugar, faint alcohol, toast and a whiff of perfume.  Deep, dark red-brown color, head is off-white and lasting.  Flavor profile is massively malty and sugary, fruity and very gently bitter, lots of dark, dried fruit and toasty, almost roasty malts, with touches of floral sweetness and finishing with a touch of hops and peppery alcohol.  Very nicely integrated and complex.  Smooth and low in effervescence, lightly coating mouthfeel, body is nicely full.  This is amazing stuff.

750 ml bottle - thanks to springslicker for the trade a while back!! sat in the fridge for a while but had ling wanted to break out; happy b-day clint thanks thanks for the great tasting!!  pours hazy dark brown with trace white head and ever mild pop upon opening; mild oxidized aromas mixed with rich sugars, dark fruits, cinnamon, oranges and spice from the booze; wow, drinks soft, rich and full of malty goodness; a little syrupy and flat; vanialla, dough and cookies come out too; decedent indeed and this has aged very well; killer brew and well worth the wait

750ml courtesy of suzygreenburg.  Youre fucking out Alex!  Hazy dark caramel brown with a ring head around the edge of my snifter.  Brown sugar, caramel (yeah, I know it is basically the same) prune and earthy peatiness with some leather and tobacco lingering in the weeds.  My god, this is tasting nice.  The oxidation is playing so well here.  Dark fruit and tobacco and caramel just hitting on all fronts.  Thanks Ben!

750, capped and foiled. thanks, suzygreenberg! pours an opaque ebony with a dense creamy tan head. big dark fruit, roast, and molasses nose. creamy medium body with softly understated carb. bounteous 
mid palate of figs, raisins, molasses and roasty malt all over the place. amazingly complex and harmonious. beautiful.

750 ml bottle - purchased in 2005 and kept in my basement at a fairly stable temp since then. Pours a fairly clear ruby red color with smallish tan head that dissipates fairrly quickly. Aroma is full of nutty caramel, notes of herbal hops, fresh pears, orange and lemon zest, roasted apples and brandy soaked raisens, faint bourbon notes, light untoasted oak, touch of chocolate. Flavor is fairly nutty, lots of toasted caramel, light oak, herbal hops, faint chocolate notes. Finish is mildly sweet, with a bit of alcohol warmth as it drops down. Overal this is a very nice brew. I had a bottle a couple of years ago, but didnt rate it at the time. It still has a bit of alcohol strength to it, but more smooth than when last I tried it. The nose is nicely complex, and although the flavor does not quite match the aroma, it is still very nice. A quality brew, that has aged well and I am sure is not yet at its peak.

Bottle from Stuffed Sandwich split by Shyam.  Nose of thick grapey malt, dark chocolate and oxidation.  Color is a reddish black purple.  Flavor is very thick malt, fruit syrup, slight chocolate, and reminiscent of both Speedway and Dec 06 in its yeast character and texture.  Staved off oxidation like nobodys business.

750ml bottle courtesy of CaptainCougar at the DC Local Gathering.  Big bourbon aroma.  Brownish-black color.  Some creamy porter-like qualities with strong alcohol and bourbon nuances throughout.  A slow sipper, to be savored.  Thick and syrupy finish, some mild heat.
Thanks SoLan.  You the man!  Cloudy brown.  Aroma of dark fruits, black licorice and brown sugar with a nice alcohol kick.  Still drinking nicely.  Awesome.

Sampled, not really a fair rating. Pretty much dominated by caramel and toffee in the aroma with some sweet malt to, Taste was a bit boozy with lots of sweet malt,ripe dark fruit  and caramel. Some burnt sugar aswell.

Poured a ruby/brown color with good head and nice lacing. 
Nose is huge on vanilla. 
Flavor is surprisingly still boozy, sweet stone fruits, figs, lots of toffee on the finish.
Thanks to Odeed for sharing this, and letting me crash at his place! Pours deep opaque ruddy brown. with no head. Bourbon and dark fruit nose. Same in the flavor with a smooth mouthfeel.

Huge thanks to moejuck for sending me this beer. I have been waiting a very long time to try it. After joining ratebeer the first half of 06 I realized by late in 06 I needed this beer but couldnt find it anywhere in the SD county area. Thank you Joe. Pours  copper brown with light copper edges and thin tan head. The aroma is yummy rich dark fruitiness with dates, prunes and mashed aged cherries blending together and mixing with a nice layer of caramel goodness and some booziness. The taste has smooth barleywine notes with a pulse of smooth sweetness from dates, figs, prunes, raisins and minced sugar stewed cherries. Toward midway a thin river of caramel is noticed just as blunted pine hops with aged bitterness come to the surface. It smooths out even more into the finish with dark sweet grape jam, smooth chewy malts and fading aged pine hops. This was everything I was hoping for. YUM!

750ml bottle.  Been wanting to open this one for a while.  Pours deep brown with a reddish hue, a 1 finger thick beige head left behind some nice lacing.  Tons of toffee and caramel on the nose as well as some dried apricots and peaches.  Flavor was quite sweet toffee, candied tree fruits and a touch of booze.  It seem like this beer might have hit its peak about 6 months ago, light oxidation in both the aroma and flavor, still a killer beer none the less!

bottle courtesy of Ibrew2or3s generous 05-07 vertical! Poured an amber brown. BOOZE! Love it. Smelled musky, sweet, fruity and very malty. Flavor was warming alcohol, tons of rich dark fruits, sweet malts and toffee. Smooth finish. Amazing beer!

Bottle courtesy of Ibrew2or3. Pours a dark brown with reddish amber highlights and thin white head. Aroma is sweet and malty with notes of run-soaked raisins, ripe dark fruit, molasses, brown sugar, hints of honey and spice. Flavor is sweet and malty with notes of ripe dark fruit, caramel, boozy bourbon, chocolate, molasses, hints of brown sugar and spice, Generally medium to full body with a pleasing malty and boozy finish.

Bottle thanks to Ibrew2or3 for the share!  Poured a dark, cloudy honey color with a thin beige head.  Nose is quite boozy with hints of over-ripe fruit rasin maybe, wood, and hops.  Medium bodied with a decent amount of carbonation.  Flavor is vinous with strong caramel malt notes, rasin or prune, wood, and quite a bit of tongue burning alcohol.  Dry boozy finish with notes of sherry.  Nice.

courtesy of ibrew2or3.
pours copperish / brown with thin off white head, and nice golden lacing.
Aroma caramel malts, plenty of dark fruits for a resinous flavors.
Taste, caramel malts, grainy, light bitter finish, some cocoa nibs, insanely smooth and drinkable with a toffee like palate.

Lots of thanks to IBrew2or3 for sharing this vertical of Decadence.  This one pours a hazy brown with an off-white head.  Nose is raisin, whiskey, vanilla, dark fruits, and a ton of malt.  Flavor is underlied with whiskey, and is generally boozy.  I also get some caramel, raisin, alcohol, vinuous notes, and just lots of goodness.  Smooth like most AleSmith beers and medium-bodied.  Very enjoyable and goes down with some alcohol burn.  Too bad I wasnt into beer in 2005!

Bottle poured reddish brown with small off white head. Aroma was dark fruits, alcohol. Taste was dark fruits, raisons, and malt. texture was smooth as a babys bottom, and glides down into my belly. Very nice brew and aged very well.

This was the first beer of the night.... Nose was close to a Barleywine. Lots of raison and dark fruits in the nose. Taste was the same. Dark fruits, raisons and malty with lots of age. The texture was perfect as all alesmith beers are. Super smooth and easy to drink. The best beer of the night IMO... Lots of thanks to wolf for sharing
Classy as hell, fizzy, thick, warming liqueur flavor, cha,pagny, dry, little nuttiness. Brown sugar comes out as it warms and sits. Thanks Daknole.
Bottle from moejuck.  Thanks Joe!  Reddish brown in color.  Off white head  Sweet malty aroma with honey and hops.  Flavor is full and rich.  Honey, smooth hops, caramel, fruit and some light nuts.
Dark and rich. Almost barleywine aspects to it for me. Mild oxidation and semi stale but mostly sweetness and still a mellow hop presence. A roasty nutty bitterness. Pretty good.

Rather ugly looking one with a small bubly head. Aroma is warm and inviting, sort of like aproaching a roaring fire on a cold winter night, full of non-sleazy caramell malty goodness and hot fruity alcohol warmth. The body is fairly full, slick but mouthfilling. Flavour is similar to the aroma, suprisingly sharp for its age but in a neat, very potent way. Finishes on a warm, familiar note. A handcrafted, great tasting beer from a fantastic brewery.

Bottle, thanks to andersand. Oh, this felt like a real rare treat. Brown color. Damn good aroma of toffee, dried fruits, caramel, spices and even some honey. Quite sweet malty flavour with lots of caramel, dried fruits, honey and almonds. Warming and nice finish, overall very fruity. Wonderful smooth palate, fullbodied. Wow!

750 ml gold foiled wrapped bottle sent to me from TheBeerSommelier, thanks a ton Matt for this retired gem. The pour is not that attractive but hell this bottle is over 3 years old now. The outer most edges are a deep burnt orange with a chestnut brown center. The head on this one is a small bubbly beige that is only visible with a very vigorous pour. The aroma on this one has really come on nicely with notes of toffee, wood, caramel, raisin, slight vinous notes, fermenting honey. Medium palate on this one with the softest touch of carbonation and suprisingly all of the alcohol heat for an 11% beer has faded. Flavor is toffee, wood, caramel, slight rum notes, grain. Excellent beer that Im glad I got try and since Im doing an entire 750ml 11% ABV by myself Im also glad that Im off tomorrow.

.. like a caramelized plum, oh ya .. . medium brown tawny color .. . nice foam .. .quite hot still, but insanely drinkable .. . hot sherry and chocolate flavours  . . nice and smooth .. . very balanced.. delicious .. could age longer .. . has a hint of boccie ..

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2011 2010 bottle courtesy of BrewEngineer on 10/22/2010. Clear caramel amber body with a small creamy tan head. Sweet caramel and molasses aroma. Sweet caramel, light fruit and dry molasses flavor. Medium full body with moderately low carbonation.
8/3/8/3/16 - 3.8

Bottle courtesy of Numenor on 03/14/2009. 2005 English Style Old Ale. Somewhat hazy dark amber body with a small creamy off-white head. Big caramel, molassas and earthy malt aroma with some earthy hop notes. Sweet caramel, molassas and earthy malt flavor, more earthy malt. Very smooth silky caramel finish. Medium full body with moderate carbonation.
8/4/8/4/16 - 4.0

A beautiful dark mahogony body with a light ivory head.  Aroma is amazing, nice alcohol hotness with some caramel and dark fruits.  Taste is smooth, plums, bananas, cherry with some nice molassas.  Ending has a slight spice with a very nice smooth ending.  Great beer and I’m glad I held onto this one.

750 mL bottle shared by Numenor. Thanks! Pours a dark brownish red colro with a very thin head. Poor retention and lacing. Aroma of chocolate, raisin, citrus and earthy hops. Taste is bitter citrus and pine hops with toffee and dark fruits. Full bodied.

I got this in a trade with a Cali BA, either oodeftone or Metallitone1, cant remember. Either way, thanks! I went into this already having tasted the barrel-aged version first and not havign had this fresh. It was a dark ruby-orange, decent head at first, looks similar to the barrel-aged but less murky. Nice smells of candy, grapes, cognac and barleywine. The flavor was toffee, caramel, really nice. I will say this is better barrel-aged because it adds a boozy, bourbon-vanilla but still the regular version is an excellent barleywine/old ale and the 11% ABV is completely hidden. Im glad I still have one bottle of the BA version, mmmm.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-10-2008 05:32:55

UPDATED: MAY 8, 2009 Cloudy amber.  Chewy aroma has lots of caramel.  Big chewy body but with a soft milk chocolate character.  Robust alcohol finish is also a little bit candyish.  I dont remember having this when it came out, but Im not sure this is coming together now...just lots of malt and nothing really special.   Re-rate A few months later, tackling this again and while I enjoy the soft brown sugar note, there arent that many elements to cheer about.  I scored it a bit higher and my numbers will reflect both samplings.

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2010 1/8/2009

2005 bottle graciously provided by bockyhorsey...

pours hazy a rich chestnut-y auburn brown with a small tan head and a bunch of spotty lacing.

the aroma has distinct barrel aged qualities to it yet it has not seen wood... oak, vanilla, tons of cognac spiciness, brown sugar, orange and cocoa butter. theres a nice oxidized/aged smell in the background that i am really digging into. 

the palate is sweet for sure but never reaches cloying. astringency and nearly bitter spiciness clean off any residue and alcohol lends a hand to clean off the tongue.... the flavor has some caramel, cocoa butter, coffee, clove, cinnamon and vanilla in addition to the aroma profile... so rich. decadent possibly?

medium bodied with a lux mouth feel and the perfect amount of carbonation. bitterness and spice make it really easy to keep drinking!
8/4/8/4/16/4.0

Sample courtesy of Bockyhorsey at the hellbilly holiday tasting.  Hazy deep chestnut color with a small ring of head.  Aroma of sweet ripe fruit and alcohol.  Flavor of roasted caramel malt, dark fruit, a bit of coffee and chocolate.  Some bitterness shows up on the finish.  Really good stuff.  Thanks Bill!

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2015 2005 Bottle aged approximately one year.Raw, fresh and messy in the nose, it certainly has that unpasteurized, unfiltered feel to it that is so appealing about alesmith.  Unfortunately, the hops are decidedly obnoxious and burst forth with cherry, lychee, grapefruit and orange peel notes, dominating the aroma and limiting the malt presence to a sugary chocolate-meets-caramelized raisin.  The flavor, then, is not surprisingly heavy on the hops and Im amazed at how bitter and bold they are after a year in the bottle.  Oranges and ruby red grapefruit dominate the opening, with a wash of toffee in the middle that is in turn enveloped by staunch bitterness and alcohol on the end.  Low carbonation, and fat malts lead to a typical hop lovers mess but as usual, I dont approve.  Would be more interested to try a bottle with 3 years of age on it now.  Interesting, anyways, and wholesome, but too messy for me.2010 Decadence bottle drunk 8/14/15.Well, the hops certainly werent a problem this time and as far as old ales go, it does have some enjoyable malt flavors of toffee, caramel, plums, raisins, vanilla and the alcohol somewhat dries it out.  But in the end, the oxidation, combined with just too much booze and soggy-sweet flavors just dosent have any appeal for me whatsoever.  Scored the same, but for different reasons.

Sample courtesy of bockyhorsey at hellbilly*s holiday tasting.  Pours a hazy amber with a light tan head.  Nose is fruity malty alcohol.  Taste is molasses, dark fruits, brown sugar and toffee.  Medium fairly flat mouth feel.  Very good.  Thanks Bill!

Bottle thanks to Sam at Stuffed Sandwiches - bottle shared with bman1113vr.
Pours with a dark amber hue that sit belows a small light brown head that is mostly diminishing. 
Aroma is of dark fruits, berries, molasses, caramel, and alcohol.
Flavor is sweet in the beginning, and slightly bitter in the end notes. There is a warming alcohol sensation as one sips this brew. Beer also coats the mouth pretty well.
Syrupy texture with lively carbonation. 
A great treat indeed!

UPDATED: JUN 29, 2010 2005 Version : Bottle thanks to Sam at Stuffed Sandwiches for what I consider a steal at 17 dollars.  Pours with a light brown bubbly head and a murky dark amber body with some yeasties. Acceptable lacing, but nothing special, but good for an 11 percent 4 year old beer. Aroma of dark fruits, berries, chocolate caramel and a slight vinous note. Very decadent. Taste is caramel, berries, toffee, dried and dark fruits with a vinous and yeasty note. Currants and raisins dominate as it warms. Syrupy and creamy mouthfeel that completely coats while the alcohol warms you. Bubbles were in the background and didnt detract from the amazing drinking experience. 948516:4.2
2010 version: Bottle (($12.99). Pours with a medium sized tan head over a hazed deep brown body. Aromas of strong brown sugar, molasses and caramel. Rich, decadent and deep, light dark fruits. I am opening this a bit cold, so it might need to warm a bit to give me its full bouquet, but I can tell you, even cold it smells fantastic!. Toffee! Some anise, cola, sarsaparilla, chocolate. Taste is rich, cola, chocolate, toffee, light burnt caramel. Quite a lot of kettle caramelization. Burnt toffee, molasses, awesomeness! Big bodied, but creamy and smooth. Excellent. Even fresh this is within .2 of the 3.5 year aged version I have had previously. I am giddy in anticipation of the barrel aged version. 947416: 4.0!

25 oz bottle, consumed Aug 2008.  Pours a beautiful clear amber to dark copper body with a small fizzy beige head that faded to a thin ring.  Lotsa carbonation visible.  The nose is richly malty with dark caramel, burnt toffee, cocoa, figs, and marzipan.  Some very light sherry like oxidation, and a touch of alcohol.  Reminds me in alot of ways of aged North Coast Old Stock.  The flavor reminds me of NC Old Stock as well.  Big rich and deep toffee and caramel maltiness with perfect attenuation, it’s not cloying or tiring on the palate at all.  I really love the aged character of this, it has really mellowed and smoothed out incredibly from when it was fresh and rather hot.  The alcohol is reallty minimally noticable.  Finishes with a little cocoa and fig fruitiness, maybe even a touch of coffee.  The feel of it is just so smooth and easy drinking it’s extremely hard to believe that this is 10% ABV.  Sometimes I’m a big stickler for carbonation and the soft gentle nature of this suits it well.  I had to break out an 04 NC Old Stock to drink side by side with this, and while the OS is a bit darker and has a bit more toffee, the comparison has some validity.  Wish I had more of these to cellar.

Thanks to Beer_Hawk for sharing this one!
Pours a clear dark amber with a lasting off-white head.
Complex aroma dark fruits, caramel, raisin.
The flavor follows the aroma. 
Very tasty sipper that is holding up (improving?) very well.
Yummy.

Bottle. Poured brown with an off-white head that settles out with time. Good mix of caramel malts and fruits with a slight hint of alcohol. The flavor finds caramel, chocolate, and some fruits with a very slight alcohol presents. Medium to full body that is sweet up front and bitter in the end. Very nice!

Sample at J Gumbos Aug 2008  Indy tasting - I’ve been holding this and the BA version for the right tasting and this was it.  Aroma of prune, plum, dark malts, chocolate, caramel, toffee and alcohol.  Flavor matches with some tobacco on top.  There’s a lot going on.  Palate is sticky.  A tasty brew for sure.

Aged over 3 years.  This special brew pours a dark and hazy, reddish brown color.  A small, frothy, tan colored head settles quickly to a thin film, sugary legging showing in place of any lacing.  The aroma is heavily malt driven, massive notes of decadent English toffee, caramel, and a sherry-like fruit profile all on full display.  The hop profile is mostly earthy and very lightly spicy, lending a touch of balance to this malt monster.  Flavors again feature toffee and caramel prominently, hints of vanilla, cherry, and fig adding fruity depth.  Big and silky smooth in the mouth, the syrupy, liquor-like texture is surprisingly void of cloying stickiness.  This is another fantastic beer from a can’t miss brewer.

Oxidationfest Tasting at illinsmittys curtesy of Beerhawk.  2005.  This is a superb example of style.  The translucent dark amber with a reddish tint, a few shades lighter than the barrel aged, and no head.  Dark rum soaked fruit aroma, some vanilla, and a hint of hops, a littler harsher than the aged.  Flavor is  dark cherry, some anise, not as sweet as the barrel aged.  This is very smooth, medium full body.  Very enjoyable.

Bottle from Beer Hawk. Thanks mucho hombre! Pours orange amber with an off white head. Aroma of sugary malts, sherry, and alcohol. As with all of Alesmith beers, great earthy mouthfeel. Texture is slightly syrupy, but with no stickiness. Flavor of sherry, caramel, and toffee that is countered by a faded hop bitterness. Some very slight smoke phenols on the finish, with the alcohol warmth but no bite. This is past its prime, but is aging gracefully. No cardboard, but nice sherry notes.

750ml bottle shared by egajdzis. Thanks!!!  Poured a cloudy deep amber in color with a quickly diminishing tan head. Aroma of toffee, chocolate, dark fruits, and a little smoke. Tastes of sweet toffee, brown sugar, chocolate with a hefty amount of alcohol warming in the finish. Thanks Eric.

UPDATED: DEC 8, 2009 ++++ Re Rate 7 December 2009 ++++
750 ml bottle shared by Indra. Pour is a slight haze golden orange cordovan with a smallish light tan head. Head breaks down to bigger bubbles. Aroma of dusty earthy hazelnut maltiness, some floral, some light oxidation way in the back. Behind all of this is some dry fruit which shows some mild cherry sweetness. Taste is mild soft caramel sweetness, the hazelnut, and followed by some resin earthiness.  It amazingly seems to have a mild resin hop bitterness. The oxidation is present, but works really nicely to meld and smooth out the flavors. Palate is medium to heavy, coats the mouth a bit, then transitions to be dry and leafy in the finish. Thanks for sharing this one Eric.  (8,4,8,3,16 - 3.9)

++++ Original Rating 12 August 2008 ++++
2005 Vintage.  750 ml bottle generously shared by tjthresh. Pour is ruby, red brown - hazed, with a tan head that falls fast with not much lacing. Aroma of soft sweet fruity caramel. Vanilla woodiness in the background of the nose. Soft, delicate, very engaging nose. Taste is nice; soft caramelly, grainy with a sharp woodiness. Some residual alcohol in the finish that doesnt detract. This was a really nice beer.  Thank you for sharing this one with me Tom, very cool of you. (8,4,8,4,16 - 4.0)

750ml from an online vendor I don’t recall. Duh, it’s been a few years. I’ve been saving this one for a very special occasion, and am pleased as punch to pop it open tonight. A deep dark red pour, with just a trace of cloudiness in there from the main ingredients, as well as a slight fizz from the carbo (still there) and some pleasant lacing. Big ass nose of multiple malts, initially with chocolate characteristics and then settling into toffee, plum, fig, and tobacco. Lovely mouthfeel, with a slight bite on the tongue that gives the brew a warming, lasting quality. Definitely akin to sipping on a beloved malt whiskey, and another Alesmith winner.

Wow!  Pours a hazy dark red with very little head.  Big chewy melted English Toffee nose.  Tons of toffee with some nice oxidized notes.  Some chocolate syrup.  There’s a little bit of bitterness at the end with some lingering alcohol.  Really damn good.  Full bodied and hardly any noticeable carbonation.  Kind of a fudgey sweet finish, but very easy to drink.  This beer is outstanding in every way.

Bottle thanks to Drewbeerme.  Dirty brown red with small beige head.  Aroma of oxidized alc, red fruit, very nice.  Flavor is once again oxidized alc bwith red fruit but it comes off being much more boozy.  Medium body and surprisingly well carbonated and smoooth.  Big alc and over oxidized but I can see where this might have been better when it first was bottled but at the same time I could see some years improving on it as well.

750 ml bottle - Ive been sittin on this for a couple years and thought it would be a good idea to drink it soon.  Pours a hazy brown color with a thin off white film for a head which faded quickly.  Very little carbonation.  No lacing.  Aroma is dark esters, oak?, and doughy malt.  Flavor is esters, sweet toasted malt, and light alcohol.  Very little oxidation for a three year old bottle of beer.  Alcohol is noticeable.  Medium to full body.  A nice beer.

Bottle shared by iowaherkeye. Thanks joey. Boozy, earthy aroma with lots of fig and molasses. Poured a slightly hazy orange brown color with a soapy off white head.
